Hi Henry. I'm a huge fan of your channel, and have been watching all of your videos as they come out. I'm currently doing an honours degree in math and physics, and going through my undergrad I really appreciated the videos that you made. The clear explantions and great stick figure drawings get the ideas across really well.

Anyway, I wanted to say that at about 0:20 you say that it takes light 4.5seconds to travel through the sun and you arn't sure if it's due to the sun's size and/or if it's the speed of light that's slowing down. Well here is how I understand it:

The mean free path is the average distance a photon travels before it interacts with a particle. In the centre of the sun the mean free path is relatively a lot shorter than that of a photon in free space because of the increased opacity and density in the middle of the sun due to the strong gravitional forces.  Because of these interactions, a photon in the center takes an incredibly long and complex path before it finally emerges from the surface.

So the photon still travels at the speed of light but the path it takes is so much longer due to the interactions with all these closely packed particles in the core of the sun. For clarity, here's a well made diagram that I found showing you what I'm trying to explain: http://abyss.uoregon.edu/~js/images/mean_free_path.gif

I hope this helped!  :)
